report_title: Commercial Real Estate in the US
executive_summary: The Commercial Real Estate industry comprises a diverse set of operators that specialize in a variety of real estate activities, including brokerage, property and facilities management, research and analytics, consulting, valuation, appraisal, construction and asset management. Changes within the commercial real estate market, including fluctuations in vacancy rates, property values and credit activity, influence demand for industry services. During periods of economic downturn, low business activity lessens demand for additional office buildings, retail centers, hotels, apartment buildings, manufacturing plants and other commercial spaces. As property owners and developers do not require new space, demand for commercial real estate falls.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Commercial Real Estate Saw Strong Pre-Pandemic Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2018 and 2019, a strong macroeconomic environmentâ€”as indicated by rising consumer spending and corporate profitâ€”lead to growth in the commercial real estate industry. The rising value of private nonresidential construction translated to higher fees and overall performance for operators in the commercial real estate industry. Cheap access to capital through low interest rates kept demand high even as property became more expensive.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Hurt the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 played a significant role in affecting short and long-term trends across the commercial real estate market, as revenue declined due to slumping valuation of private nonresidential construction. The closure of nonessential businesses at the height of the pandemic drove down revenue from commercial real estate. The shift to working from home, as evidenced by high office vacancy rates, has had a longer-term impact on commercial real estate than lockdown related business closures, as working from home seems to have been a more lasting cultural shift.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Following the Pandemic, High Interest Rates Have Hurt the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Federal Reserve have been raising interest rates recently in an effort to stem inflation which arose from rapid economic expansion coming out of the pandemic in 2021, with the latest Federal Funds Target rate ranging from 5.25%-5.50%. High interest rates have raised the cost of capital, driving down activity in the commercial real estate industry, which is often extremely capital intensive. Office rental vacancies are set to peak in 2023, indicating that demand for commercial real estate (particularly office space) has been dampened, aided by high interest rates.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Long Term Sources of Growth Continue to Underpin Commercial Real Estate
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The commercial real estate industry, both extremely large in value and wide ranging in operations and services, rises and falls along with the broader US and global economies. Population growth underpins the growing value of commercial real estate as a larger population broadly creates more overall economic activity, including in the commercial real estate industry. US GDP has seen overall growth in recent years, indicating a broader base of economic activity on which the commercial real estate industry can build.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: High Inflation and Rising Interest Rates Continue to Influence Broader Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As long as high inflation remains high, interest rates will remain elevated, depressing growth in the commercial real estate industry. High interest rates have the two-fold effect of making capital needed for constructing and buying property more expensive and of making bonds a more attractive investment relative to real estate. Interest rates are expected to ultimately fall from their current heights over the coming years, though they are not expected to reach the lows seen in recent years. As interest rates eventually fall in the coming years, construction, transactions and investment activity in the commercial real estate industry should see growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling Office Vacancies Poised to Accelerate Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Office rental vacancies are set to hit their peak in 2023, pointing to strengthening demand for commercial real estate as vacancies fall moving forward. While office rental vacancies are set to fall moving forward, they are expected to remain above pre-pandemic levels, as economic recovery and a return-to-office trend takes over the market. Many businesses have shifted to hybrid work, which could require a smaller footprint of commercial real estate, or to remote work, which, of course, requires none. Because of this, demand for specifically office space could see a permanent dampening in certain sectors of the economy.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation of Services Set to Diversify Revenue Streams
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Moving forward, property owners and lessors will increasingly turn to property managers, real estate consultants and asset managers to reduce costs and improve profitability. Property managers will expand their service offerings to encompass more tenant-related services including facility management. The Property management industry (IBISWorld report 53131) is set to see overall growth in the coming years, supporting growth in the wider commercial real estate industry. As home price growth continues to outpace wage growth, residential real estate will continue to become less available to the average person, leading to a greater demand for rental housing and supporting the commercial real estate industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Commercial Real Estate Construction is Set to Grow
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Commercial real estate construction, part of the wider commercial real estate industry, is set to see growth in the coming years. Eventually falling interest rates, a general shortage of housing, a growing population and overall economic growth will all be positive drivers for commercial real estate construction. The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 will provide funding for construction projects meant to reduce the nation's greenhouse gas emissions. The 2022 CHIPS and Science Act provides for funding for domestically produced semiconductors, which will benefit the construction segment of the industry in coming years. Demand for industrial real estate is particularly important as demand for office space weakens.

industry_definition: The Commercial Real Estate industry consists of companies that construct or develop commercial, industrial and multifamily residential property or provide commercial real estate services including renting, leasing, managing.
key_trends: Most companies only operate in a small segment of the industry.
Overall industry competition is therefore low.
Most operators are nonemployers. Still, a few large companies in commercial real estate operate on a global scale.
Commercial real estate revenue was growing before the COVID-19 pandemic. A strong macroeconomic environment and low interest rates boosted the industry.
The COVID-19 pandemic set commercial real estate back. As working from home proliferated and supply chain issues held up construction, revenue fell.
Current high interest rates are hurting the industry. Along with continued supply chain issues, a lack of access to capital due to high interest rates have caused the industry to continue its decline
As a large and varied industry, there are many companies. None accounts for more than 2.0% of revenue.
Office rental vacancies are expected to peak in 2023. Falling vacancies will drive demand for the office segment.
Financial services in the commercial real estate industry face regulation. REITs, for example, face specific organizational and operational guidelines.
The construction sector is facing increased purchase costs. Widespread supply chain issues in the wake of the pandemic have driven up the cost of materials.
Commercial real estate's average profit margin has fallen. This is due to wage and purchase cost shares of revenue rising.
Business locations broadly have the same spread as the population. The wide variety of industry operations means most populations are a source of demand.
Major centers of business earn more revenue. Cities like New York, Philadelphia and Los Angeles attract more consistent streams of revenue.
Construction has been hampered by supply chain issues. These issues have increased costs at the same time as interest rates have risen, making it harder to pay those costs.
Offices have taken a hit from the increased popularity of working from home. Office rental vacancies are expected to peak in 2023, but pre-pandemic occupancy rates aren't in sight.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes demand for commercial real estate used as office space.
This segment includes demand from retailers and from hotels, both of which seek property in high-trafficked areas.
This segment includes construction, leasing, management and other services related to the residential market, which is primarily apartment buildings and complexes.
This market segment accounts for industry revenue from hospitals, schools, universities, churches, prisons and other government buildings.
This segment includes industrial properties with tenants engaged in a wide variety of businesses, including manufacturing, wholesale trade, distribution and professional services.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes building and remodeling activity of commercial properties, typically done by general contractors.
This segment includes the leasing of multifamily residential properties (i.e., apartment buildings, or residential properties with five or more units).
This segment includes rent and other related fees property owners earn from commercial real estate.
This segment includes revenue earned by agents or brokers on either side of a commercial real estate sale.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Property and Asset Management and Consulting
products_and_services.product_description: Property managers are responsible for the daily operation of a property and act as a liaison between owners and tenants. Real estate asset managers and consultants provide long-term strategic planning for clients investing in real estate.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The value of nonresidential construction directly influences the commissions received by real estate agents and brokers, affecting the performance of other real estate services included in the industry.

business_locations.location_description: Home to major centers of business including New York City and Philadelphia, the Mid-Atlantic generates the most revenue for the industry.
Home to a large share of the nation's population, including California, the most populous state.
The Southeast region is the largest market in the Commercial Real Estate industry by establishments but does not produce the largest share of industry revenue.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Commercial Real Estate industry participants are required to meet various building and safety codes before providing commercial real estate to companies and individuals.
Real estate companies and developers can elect to be taxed as a real estate investment trust (REIT).
